author: By James Poniewozik
title: ‘Impeachment’ Review: A She Said, She Said Situation
description: The mini-series sees the Clinton saga through the eyes of the women involved, but struggles to add to a much-told story.
content: One thing that jumps out at you in the opening hour of FX’s “Impeachment: American Crime Story” is how layered it is. And by “layered,” I refer to the makeup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: After a Cataclysm, the Nature Lovers in ‘Harrow’ Struggle to Stay Sane
description: Joy Williams’s fifth novel is about a teenager named Khristen who washes up at a retreat filled with elderly eco-warriors.
content: After the coming apocalypse, when prizes are handed out for the best novels that presaged our end, Joy Williams’s new one, “Harrow,” will be a contender in the experimental category. Our mutant overlord critics will ask about it, squatting around a pixelated campfire, wearing goggles, sucking the marrow from squirrel bones, “What the hell was that?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: For U.S. Men, Two Games and No Wins Add Up to Concern
description: After settling for disappointing draws in its first two World Cup qualifiers, the U.S. men’s soccer team heads to Honduras in search of answers, and its first victory.
content: NASHVILLE — If every World Cup qualifying campaign is a roller-coaster ride of highs and lows, then the United States men’s soccer team has not yet left the ground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich and Chang W. Lee
title: Taekwondo Takes Its First Spin at the Paralympics
description: Almost 70 athletes from 35 countries competed in Tokyo as the sport made its Paralympic debut.
content: Taekwondo, the Korean martial art that features a dazzling array of spinning and chopping kicks, made its Paralympic debut in Japan. The Games ended on Sunday, with 68 athletes from 35 countries competing in taekwondo under the klieg lights at a large convention hall just outside Tokyo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Villarosa
title: Dawn Turner Looks Back on Her ’70s Girlhood, and Those Who Got Left Behind
description: “Three Girls From Bronzeville” follows three close-knit children as they grow up to become radically different women.
content: THREE GIRLS FROM BRONZEVILLE A Uniquely American Memoir of Race, Fate, and Sisterhood By Dawn Turner
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Patricia Maginnis, Pioneering Abortion-Rights Activist, Dies at 93
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, September 6, 2021.
content: “After all she went through, including risking going to prison, she couldn’t have imagined this kind of rollback.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eleanor Henderson
title: Why Did Two People So Poorly Matched Stay Together So Long?
description: Christopher Sorrentino’s memoir, “Now Beacon, Now Sea,” examines the endurance and effects of his parents’ confounding marriage.
content: NOW BEACON, NOW SEAA Son’s MemoirBy Christopher Sorrentino
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rothenberg
title: Emma Raducanu Storms Into U.S. Open Quarterfinals
description: The ascending British star efficiently beat the American Shelby Rogers 6-2, 6-1, to advance to the final eight in only her second Grand Slam. The 18-year-old has yet to drop a set in New York.
content: The most inexperienced players also looked the most comfortable in the first week of the U.S. Open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: As Afghan Refugee Crisis Unfolds, Survivors Recall ‘Miracle’ Evacuation
description: The U.S. military evacuated 91,000 people out of a North Korean port in 1950. By some estimates, it was the single largest wartime refugee evacuation in American history until Afghanistan.
content: SEOUL — When he watched the scenes of desperate refugees trying to escape Afghanistan during the American withdrawal ㅡ mothers clutching babies, men begging to board airplanes in Kabul — Sohn Yang-young, 70, felt tears welling up in his eyes, his heart aching as if he were there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sami Sahak, Wali Arian and Jim Huylebroek
title: Taliban Claim Control Over Panjshir Valley, but Resistance Vows to Fight On
description: Militants posted images apparently taken in Bazarak, the capital of Panjshir Province in Afghanistan, where opposition forces have fought against their rule.
content: The Taliban claimed on Monday to have captured the Panjshir Valley, raising their flag over the last Afghan provincial capital not firmly under their control, even as representatives of the opposition forces there maintained that they would fight on from the mountains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joel Carillet
title: A Personal Pilgrimage to a Downed Warplane in Papua New Guinea
description: Thirty-three years after his first visit to the site, a photographer traveled to a remote jungle in search of a World War II plane that crashed there in 1944.
content: Early in the afternoon of April 5, 1944, an A-20 Havoc, wrestling with apparent engine trouble after an attack on the Japanese stronghold of Hollandia (present-day Jayapura, Indonesia), withdrew from formation and fell from the sky. It vanished into a thick jungle canopy, exploding on impact. On board were Second Lt. Thomas Freeman, 23, and Cpl. Ralph A. McKendrick, 22.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catharine A. MacKinnon
title: OnlyFans Is Not a Safe Platform for ‘Sex Work.’ It’s a Pimp.
description: The company’s decision to reverse course on a proposed ban of “sexually explicit” content shows the power of pornography.
content: We are living in the world pornography has made. For more than three decades, researchers have documented that it desensitizes consumers to violence and spreads rape myths and other lies about women’s sexuality. In doing so, it normalizes itself, becoming ever more pervasive, intrusive and dangerous, surrounding us ever more intimately, grooming the culture so that it becomes hard even to recognize its harms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: At the Telluride Film Festival, Both Magic and Normalcy
description: In movies as different as “King Richard,” about Venus and Serena Williams’s father, and “Petite Maman,” filmmakers can’t stop thinking about children.
content: TELLURIDE, Colo. — Masks were mandatory in the screening rooms, as well as in the shuttle vans and gondola cars that ferry cinephiles around this gilded former mining town over the Labor Day weekend. If you had a badge, it meant you also had a vaccination and a negative Covid test. Attending the Telluride Film Festival has always meant waiting in a lot of lines, and there was a new queue this year, outside a tent at the edge of a park where you could get your nostrils swabbed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy
title: An Unsung Pit Crew of California’s Wildfires: Hotel Workers Left Behind
description: As ash falls from the Caldor fire, skeleton staff stay to feed and refuel thousands of firefighters battling the blaze.
content: STATELINE, Nev. — From the casino where she works, Nathalia Bonifacio watched the world flee. Thousands of tourists, homeowners and workers who keep the economy humming along Lake Tahoe streamed out of town in the last two weeks as a wildfire roared closer through the Sierra Nevada.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: Nick Cave Digs Deep, With a Symphony in Glass
description: For his new installation of mosaics in New York, the artist ventures below Times Square.
content: On a blistering afternoon in late August, a dedicated crew of construction workers moved through the corridor connecting Times Square and Grand Central Station, home to the 42nd Street Shuttle. Here, under the streets of New York, over two dozen figures made of vibrant glass danced along the subway walls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan and Jennifer Steinhauer
title: Americans Stretch Across Political Divides to Welcome Afghan Refugees
description: “Even the most right-leaning isolationists” are coming forward to help those fleeing Afghanistan, a pastor said. A mass mobilization is underway.
content: PHOENIX — The hundreds of parishioners at Desert Springs Bible Church, a sprawling megachurch in the northern suburbs of Phoenix, are divided over mask mandates, the presidential election and what to do about migrants on the border. But they are unified on one issue: the need for the United States to take in thousands of Afghan evacuees, and they are passing the plate to make it happen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Harris, Shikeith and Alex Harrington
title: A Cautionary Tale for the New Roaring Twenties
description: What does “The Wild Party,” an obscure but chillingly prescient book-length poem from the twilight of the Jazz Age, tell us about our own era?
content: THERE ARE FEW things more glamorous than the belief that we are living through the end of an era — and there are even fewer times in recent history when we haven’t believed it. It’s a conviction that allows us to ennoble ourselves with pathos, with rueful maturity, with wisdom won too late. To be certain that we’re at the beginning of something can mean feeling optimistic and openhearted about the future in a way that, especially these days, risks courting contempt. And to know that we’re in the middle of an era is — well, it’s not even a phrase, is it? It’s nothing much at all, simply a kind of semipermanent Wednesday of the soul, a spirit-flattening acceptance of stasis and complacency. But nearing the end? In that, you have a lifetime’s worth of wistfulness, and perhaps some bitterness and grief, not to mention prescience about what might come next. In short, life at the end of an era is — to use a term that might be coming to the end of its own era — lit. And it almost doesn’t matter if the lighting is seductive and flattering or as harsh and glaring as if the music has just been turned off and the club is about to close. Drama is drama.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Lyman
title: Jean-Paul Belmondo, Magnetic Star of the French New Wave, Dies at 88
description: He was compared to Marlon Brando and James Dean for his acclaimed portrayals of tough, alienated characters, most memorably in Godard’s “Breathless.”
content: Jean-Paul Belmondo, the rugged actor whose disdainful eyes, boxer’s nose, sensual lips and cynical outlook made him the idolized personification of youthful alienation in the French New Wave, most notably in his classic performance as an existential killer in Jean-Luc Godard’s “Breathless,” died on Monday at his home in Paris. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett Berk
title: Selling Hot New Cars at Pebble Beach, the Land of Classics
description: There’s money in the air at Monterey Car Week, so where better to sell a rare new Bugatti or Ferrari?
content: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif. — The Pebble Beach Concours d’Elegance, held since 1950, is America’s flagship classic-car show. Gawked at by thousands of sharply dressed attendees, dozens of the world’s most covetable cars compete for the prestigious Best of Show award.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: A New Way to Look at Furniture in Milan
description: A special edition of the Milan Furniture Fair, called Supersalone, turns pandemic constraints into a chance for innovation and anchors a five-day design celebration throughout the city.
content: It has been 60 years since Salone del Mobile Milano, the premier annual exhibition of furniture, was founded, and two and a half years since crowds last gathered in Milan’s exhibition halls to admire the relentless creativity of international designers and manufacturers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gwen Knapp
title: Why Ukraine’s Small Paralympic Team Packs Such a Big Punch
description: The Ukrainians finished fifth in the overall medal standings in Tokyo with 98, just six fewer than the United States, despite having a much smaller delegation.
content: TOKYO — In American sports terms, the Paralympians of Ukraine constitute a small-market marvel, the Slavic equivalent of the Oakland Athletics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Covid-19 deaths surge in the U.S.
content: A summer that began with plunging caseloads and real hope that the worst of Covid-19 had passed is ending with soaring death counts, full hospitals and a bitter realization that the pandemic is far from over in the U.S.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Terri Gerstein
title: Other People’s Rotten Jobs Are Bad for Them. And for You.
description: The impact of rotten jobs radiates far beyond the workplace.
content: A few years ago, a part-time minimum wage worker at an upstate New York McDonald’s suspected a gas leak. When he alerted his supervisors, they told him to ignore it or he’d be fired. Instead, he called the fire department, and two things happened. Firefighters found the leak and shut the restaurant for the rest of the day. And the worker was fired.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Robbins
title: Black Vulture Attacks on Animals May Be Increasing
description: But some bird experts say reports of increasing predation by black vultures in the Midwest may be overblown.
content: The scenes described of Indiana farmlands and elsewhere seem like they leapt from a page in a horror novel, with black vultures descending into the forests and pastures of the Midwest and beyond.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chang W. Lee and Gwen Knapp
title: The Moving Moments as the Paralympics Ended
description: Sights from Tokyo as the Games wrapped up.
content: TOKYO — The second and final week of the Paralympics produced some particularly moving moments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: Oregon and Idaho are running out of I.C.U. beds as Covid cases hit records.
description: Amid a Delta-driven surge in the U.S., most states have less than 30 percent of their intensive-care beds still available.
content: Oregon and Idaho have joined the list of U.S. states that are running out of I.C.U. beds as both confront a significant rise in new coronavirus infections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Threatened Birds Have a Defender on N.Y. Beaches: The Plover Patrol
description: A group of volunteers patrols beaches where endangered Piping Plovers nest.
content: Piping plovers, dun-colored shorebirds that lay their eggs in tiny scrapes in the sand, are easy to miss as they dart over the beach. Chris Allieri is harder to overlook.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: Told to ‘Find Arthur,’ I Stumbled Upon My Future at the U.S. Open
description: A father-son tournament gave our columnist almost unfettered access to players at the 1983 U.S. Open, changing the course of his life.
content: There slouched John McEnroe, the top-ranked tennis player in the world, dolefully reading a newspaper in a corner of the locker room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: From Cradle to Grave, Democrats Move to Expand Social Safety Net
description: The $3.5 trillion social policy bill that lawmakers begin drafting this week would touch virtually every American, at every point in life, from conception to old age.
content: WASHINGTON — When congressional committees meet this week to begin formally drafting Democrats’ ambitious social policy plan, they will be undertaking the most significant expansion of the nation’s safety net since the war on poverty in the 1960s, devising legislation that would touch virtually every American’s life, from conception to aged infirmity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Curtis Chang
title: A Christian’s Case Against Exemptions to Vaccine Mandates
description: There is no legitimate religious basis for exemptions from vaccine mandates in any established stream of Christianity.
content: Religious exemptions to employer mandates are a precious right in our democracy. This is why it is especially important not to offer such exemptions to coronavirus vaccine mandates. They make a mockery of Christianity and religious liberty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $4.8 Million Homes in California
description: A 1939 Georgian Revival-style estate in Monterey, a beachfront home in San Clemente and a 1928 Mediterranean-style house in San Marino.
content: This grand estate was built by George Loorz, the general contractor for Hearst Castle, in 1939. The sellers have owned the property for 20 years and have made some updates, but much of the original craftsmanship — including moldings in the living and dining rooms, and wood paneling in the library — remains intact.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Siegal
title: Colonial-Era Royal Carriage Stirs Up Modern Backlash in Netherlands
description: The “Golden Coach,” built for Queen Wilhelmina of Holland in 1896, is emerging as a new focus of debate over slavery, colonialist oppression and history.
content: AMSTERDAM — In 1896, the city of Amsterdam decided to build Queen Wilhelmina a very special gift: a carriage covered in gold. The “Golden Coach” was designed to represent the entire kingdom and its resources, with leather from Brabant, cushions filled with flax from Zeeland and teak from the Dutch colony of Java.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon
title: Palestinian Authority Indicts 14 Security Force Members in Activist’s Death
description: The family of Nizar Banat, who was known for his fierce online criticism, say more senior Palestinian officials should also face consequences after he was beaten to death.
content: HEBRON, West Bank — Fourteen members of the Palestinian Authority’s security services were charged with beating to death an outspoken activist known for his fierce online criticism, in a case that turned into a rallying cry against what critics describe as the growing authoritarianism of the Palestinian Authority.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson
title: A Century Ago, Miners Fought in a Bloody Uprising. Few Know About It Today.
description: At the Battle of Blair Mountain, thousands of miners clashed with sheriff’s deputies in the largest insurrection since the Civil War.
content: BLAIR, W.Va. — On the shoulder of a lonely stretch of highway miles into the hills, a sign stands in the weeds. “Battle of Blair Mt.,” it says, informing the tumbledown cinder block building across the road that here, 100 years ago, was the largest armed labor uprising in U.S. history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juan A. Ramírez
title: The Broadway Star Who Became One of His Generation’s Most In-Demand Voices
description: Whether he’s originating roles in musicals or on “Gossip Girl,” Adam Chanler-Berat brings range — and realism — as a new kind of character actor.
content: “I think I’m sort of exaggerating what the author meant, but there’s a bit in there that talks about gossip as an evolutionary tool to bind people together.” The actor Adam Chanler-Berat is paraphrasing the Israeli author Yuval Noah Harari’s best-selling book “Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind” (2011) on a bench near the entrance of Greenpoint’s Transmitter Park, a few blocks from the Brooklyn apartment he shares with his boyfriend, the actor Kyle Beltran. “In the days of cave people,” he explains, “gossip was ‘that person’s going to steal your food.’ It was useful!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: Minnesota Troopers Deleted Texts and Emails After Floyd Protests, Major Testifies
description: According to a transcript released Friday, a member of the Minnesota State Patrol said there was “a purge of emails and text messages” after troopers responded to protests in Minneapolis last year.
content: Minnesota State Patrol troopers deleted text messages and emails shortly after responding to protests that erupted over the police killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis last year, according to a major who testified in federal court in July.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Venice Film Festival: Elena Ferrante, Olivia Colman and Resort Horror
description: “The Lost Daughter,” like “The White Lotus” and “Nine Perfect Strangers,” takes its characters on vacation but they’re hardly getting away.
content: VENICE — Are we our best or worst selves when we go on vacation? Sure, these trips are taken with good intentions, but when you’re determined to relax, that determination can look an awful lot like work. Throw in bad weather, a crying child or downed hotel Wi-Fi, and sometimes you arrive back home in a more bedraggled state than when you left.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff and Daniele Volpe
title: As Migrants Surge Toward Border, Court Hands Biden a Lifeline
description: Desperate to control the unrelenting buildup on the border, Biden administration officials turn their focus to deterring migration, dashing hopes of asylum seekers.
content: MATAMOROS, Mexico — When the Supreme Court effectively revived a cornerstone of Trump-era migration policy late last month, it looked like a major defeat for President Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hanya Yanagihara
title: Is the Party Over or About to Begin?
description: In an era of uncertainty, it’s hard to say whether the good times have passed us by or are just around the corner.
content: WHERE ARE WE? Is this the beginning of the end, or the end of the beginning? Is the party over forever, or are the good times just around the corner? Have we already experienced the most fun we’ll ever have, or is it yet to come?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May
title: Chinese Social Media Site Suspends K-Pop Fan Accounts
description: Weibo accused one account devoted to a BTS member of illegal fund-raising amid a crackdown on 22 pages.
content: HONG KONG — One month before the 26th birthday of Park Ji-min, a member of the South Korean boy band BTS, his fans in China pooled money to plaster his photographs and a declaration of their “eternal love” on the exterior of an airplane.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Blacki Migliozzi
title: Oil Spill in the Gulf of Mexico: What We Know
description: The company leading the cleanup now says it isn’t responsible for the leak, highlighting the tangle of pipes, many of them abandoned, on the seafloor.
content: Divers searching for the origin of a substantial oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico — one of several spotted off Louisiana’s coast after Hurricane Ida — have discovered three damaged pipelines near the leak, though murky conditions on the seafloor prevented the team from finding the source.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi
title: Justice Department Says U.S. Will ‘Protect’ Texas Women Seeking Abortions
description: The statement from Attorney General Merrick B. Garland did not directly challenge a new Texas law that banned nearly all abortions in the state.
content: Attorney General Merrick B. Garland said on Monday that the Justice Department would continue to protect women who seek an abortion in Texas, days after a state law enacting a near-complete ban on the procedure went in effect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Johnson, Inviting Battle, Prepares to Break Vow on Raising Taxes
description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson is expected to propose increasing the National Insurance tax to bolster social care services.
content: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson once famously said he believed in having his cake and eating it, and during a career of dizzying highs and lows he often got what he wanted while avoiding difficult choices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs, Annie Correal, Matthew Haag and Jeremy Egner
title: Michael K. Williams, Omar From ‘The Wire,’ Is Dead at 54
description: Mr. Williams, who also starred in “Boardwalk Empire” and “Lovecraft Country,” was best known for his role as Omar Little in the David Simon HBO series.
content: Michael K. Williams, the actor who brought a hard-edge charisma to his portrayal of Omar Little, the sawed-off-shotgun-wielding stickup man on the pioneering HBO series “The Wire,” was found dead on Monday in his home in the Williamsburg neighborhood of Brooklyn, the police said. He was 54.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: ‘Billions’ Recap, Season 5, Episode 8: Back in Business
description: Chuck returns minus a beard and a lover. Axe returns minus the good sense to leave well enough alone.
content: Chuck Rhodes has shaved off his beard. But he wants to be clear: It’s not that big a deal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jared Jackson
title: Venita Blackburn Captures the Wonder, and Danger, of Young Womanhood
description: The stories in “How to Wrestle a Girl” follow characters in lust, in grief, in fear and online.
content: HOW TO WRESTLE A GIRL Stories By Venita Blackburn
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Manhunt Underway After 6 Palestinians Escape Israeli Prison
description: Four of the fugitives had been convicted of terror offenses and were serving at least two life sentences, while legal proceedings continued for the other two.
content: JERUSALEM — Six Palestinian prisoners escaped a prison in northern Israel early Monday morning, in the first such jailbreak in more than two decades, the prison service said Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: The Changing American Canon Sounds Like Jessie Montgomery
description: This composer’s music — improvisatory, open to influence, personal yet resonant — will be hard to miss in the coming season.
content: The history of classical music in the United States is one long identity crisis: the search for a homegrown sound, free from European influence. That anxiety has manifested itself time and again as self-sabotage, with some composers — almost always white men — exalted as pathbreakers, while truly original work coming from artists of color has been overlooked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: History Can Close In on Us Awfully Fast
description: Whether it’s in Texas, New York or anywhere else.
content: Gail Collins: Bret, I’ve been thinking a lot about the new Texas abortion law. Which basically bans abortions. Given the way the current Supreme Court is operating, I’m pretty sure we’re headed for a pre-1973 world, where most women facing unwelcome pregnancy had to choose between raising money for a trip to an abortion-tolerant state or risking a visit to a black-market service at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Jacob Zuma, South Africa’s Former President, Is Granted Medical Parole
description: The leader of the political opposition called the move by the country’s correctional department “entirely unlawful.”
content: Jacob Zuma, the former president of South Africa, has been released on medical parole a little over two months after he was ordered imprisoned on contempt charges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Kanye West’s ‘Donda’ Is No. 1, but Drake Waits in the Wings
description: The total for “Donda” includes 357 million streams in the United States, the most in a week so far this year.
content: Kanye West’s long-delayed new album, “Donda,” starts at No. 1 on Billboard’s new chart with the biggest opening of the year so far. But its reign at the top may be brief, with Drake’s latest LP lining up huge numbers for next week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Disputed claims over a Taliban victory in Panjshir.
content: The Taliban claimed on Monday to have captured the Panjshir Valley, raising their flag over Bazarak, the last Afghan provincial capital not firmly under their control, even as opposition forces there said that they would fight on from the mountains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson, Emmanuel Morgan and Ben Shpigel
title: Rivalries and Rookies Bloom but It’s Still Patrick Mahomes’s A.F.C.
description: The Kansas City Chiefs fortified their offensive line in pursuit of another championship, but the Bills, Browns and a bevy of first-year starters should shake up the order.
content: With back-to-back trips to the Super Bowl, it’s fair to say that the conference once ruled by Tom Brady and Peyton Manning now belongs to Patrick Mahomes and the Kansas City Chiefs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Serena Williams Is Not at the U.S. Open, but Her Coach Is Everywhere
description: Patrick Mouratoglou has become a bigger star than most players, and is building an empire, too. That does not leave much time for coaching, and that may be just how he likes it.
content: Maybe it’s the beard, the persistent, salt-and-pepper whiskers, always trimmed to a perfect length that makes Patrick Mouratoglou initially seem more like a French existentialist philosopher rather than tennis coach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: 9/11 Specials and ‘American Crime Story’
description: Several networks will air specials timed to the 20th anniversary of Sept. 11. And “American Crime Story” will return for a third season.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Sept. 6-12. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Lawyer Shot After Wife and Son Were Killed Had Been Pushed Out of Law Firm
description: Alex Murdaugh, a member of a powerful legal dynasty in South Carolina, was accused by his firm of misusing funds. A day later, Mr. Murdaugh reported that he had been shot on a rural road.
content: Alex Murdaugh, the prominent South Carolina lawyer whose wife and son were shot to death months ago in an unsolved murder mystery that has captivated the state and confounded the police, was pushed out of his powerful law firm over claims that he had misused funds the day before he called 911 from a rural road to say that he had been shot in the head, the firm disclosed on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson, Emmanuel Morgan and Ben Shpigel
title: Can Anyone in the N.F.C. Stop Tom Brady and the Bucs From Repeating?
description: Tampa Bay returns much of its Super Bowl-winning roster, but Aaron Rodgers and Davante Adams have Jordan-and-Pippen-style title dreams for Green Bay.
content: Amid the chaos and reshuffling of an N.F.L. season played during a pandemic, the 2020 season concluded with an all-too-familiar scene: Tom Brady hoisting the Lombardi Trophy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Room Dividers
description: If you don’t own a folding screen and you’re working from home, you may want to get one. Here’s why.
content: A folding screen is useful for dividing space, but it can do so much more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrea Williams
title: A Flood of New Hall of Famers, Followed by a Grinding Halt
description: Fifteen years ago, the Baseball Hall of Fame inducted 17 people from the Negro leagues. The election came with some controversy and has been followed by silence.
content: They gathered in a conference room in Vero Beach, Fla., a 12-person committee that would be both judge and jury. The weight of their task — considering the Hall of Fame worthiness of 39 Negro leagues and pre-Negro leagues players, managers, and executives — was perhaps greater than any they had carried in their careers.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Kashmir’s Poets Stifle Their Verses as Grip of Crackdown Tightens
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, September 5, 2021.
content: “In the last 30 years I have never seen this kind of suppression. There is silence everywhere, as if the silence is the best cure for our present crisis.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai and Myra Noveck
title: Twins Conjoined at the Head Separated in Israel
description: The 1-year-old twins were separated in surgery lasting over 12 hours. “For the first time, the family can hold the babies separately,” a pediatric neurosurgeon at the hospital said.
content: Surgeons in Israel have separated 1-year-old twins who were conjoined at the head, the first time the unusual surgery has been performed in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Tommasini
title: Classical Music Looks Ahead to a Fall in Flux
description: How will performances feel in the midst of pandemic regulations? Will institutions respond in actions, not just words, to calls for racial equity?
content: Normally, when I look ahead to a new season, I have a pretty good idea of what the performances will be like.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu and Lauren Hirsch
title: We’ll Give You a Week Off. Please Don’t Quit.
description: “Operation Chillax”: Companies are trying to combat burnout from working remotely by offering more time off and other perks.
content: Amy Michelle Smith loved working in advertising. But as she did her job from her one-bedroom apartment in Toronto during the remote-work months of the pandemic — months that stretched into a year and beyond — the line separating her personal life from her professional life started to fade, and she realized she was so, so tired.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas
title: The Strange Tale of the Freedom Phone, a Smartphone for Conservatives
description: A 22-year-old Bitcoin millionaire wants Republicans to ditch their iPhones for a low-end handset that he hopes to turn into a political tool.
content: It was a pitch tuned for a politically polarized audience. Erik Finman, a 22-year-old who called himself the world’s youngest Bitcoin millionaire, posted a video on Twitter for a new kind of smartphone that he said would liberate Americans from their “Big Tech overlords.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Leylah Fernandez Advances to U.S. Open Quarterfinals
description: On the eve of her 19th birthday, the young Canadian continued her magical run, beating Angelique Kerber 4-6, 7-6 (5), 6-2. She is exactly where she planned to be.
content: Less than a week ago, few casual tennis fans knew even a little, if anything, about Leylah Fernandez. When she stunned Naomi Osaka in the third round of the U.S. Open, many were more focused on the player who lost than on the player who won.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: Rupert Murdoch’s Australia News Outlets to Ease Their Climate Denial
description: The campaign, if sustained, could put pressure on Fox News, though critics were skeptical that a sea change was in store.
content: SYDNEY, Australia — After years of casting doubt on climate change and attacking politicians who favored corrective action, Rupert Murdoch’s media outlets in his native Australia are planning an editorial campaign next month advocating a carbon-neutral future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Ben Casselman
title: Unemployment Benefits Expire for Millions Without Pushback From Biden
description: The president has encouraged some states to continue helping the long-term unemployed, but administration officials said it was time for enhanced federal aid to end.
content: WASHINGTON — Expanded unemployment benefits that have kept millions of Americans afloat during the pandemic expired on Monday, setting up an abrupt cutoff of assistance to 7.5 million people as the Delta variant rattles the pandemic recovery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Clarissa Ward of CNN Looks Back on the Afghanistan War
description: The network’s chief international correspondent, one of the most visible reporters during the withdrawal of U.S. troops, decided to become a reporter after an epiphany on 9/11.
content: Clarissa Ward had four days to catch up on sleep and see her two sons, ages 1 and 3, at her parents’ home in France. Then she was off again, back to work, making her way through Qatar to Pakistan, where she reported from the Afghanistan border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon
title: Trying to Find Your Mother’s Remains From Ground Zero, 20 Years Later
description: The medical examiner’s office is still working painstakingly to identify 9/11 victims. There are 1,106 victims whose remains have not been found.
content: Last month, two detectives showed up at Nykiah Morgan’s Long Island home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: If Gawker Is Nice, Is It Still Gawker?
description: “I’m not interested in ruining people’s lives,” says its top editor, Leah Finnegan, who once insulted a baby in a headline.
content: When I started talking with Leah Finnegan, the editor of the newly restarted Gawker, I asked her whether there wouldn’t be a conflict of interest: She had been inexplicably mean to me on the internet sometime around 2013. I couldn’t recall the details but worried she’d expect a hit piece in revenge. She didn’t remember the details, either, but shared the general recollection. “I was absolutely a terrorist,” she said in a level tone, before inviting me to her walk-up apartment in Park Slope for an interview.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Tributes to Michael K. Williams, Actor Who Gave ‘Voice to the Human Condition’
description: From co-stars of “The Wire” to musicians and authors, many took to social media on Monday to share their thoughts about the actor.
content: Fans, actors and celebrities took to social media to share their condolences for Michael K. Williams, the actor best known for his role as Omar Little in the HBO series “The Wire,” who was found dead in his home on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: For American Men, U.S. Open Hints at Better Days Ahead
description: There are currently 14 men in the top 100, the most since 1996, but none in the top 20. While the United States may not have any truly elite players right now, it does have youth.
content: It took a while, but after the American Reilly Opelka and his big serve were eliminated in the fourth round of the U.S. Open on Monday by Lloyd Harris of South Africa, I decided to go searching.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: Belarus Opposition Leader Sentenced to 11 Years in Prison
description: The convictions of Maria Kolesnikova, a fierce opponent of President Aleksandr Lukashenko, and a colleague are part of a crackdown on dissent following a disputed election last year.
content: MOSCOW — A Belarusian court on Monday sentenced Maria Kolesnikova, a leading opposition figure who last year tried to run for president, to an 11-year prison sentence, another sign that President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko is pursuing an unrelenting crackdown on dissent following a heavily disputed election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Mardy Fish Can Relate to What Naomi Osaka Is Going Through
description: Anxiety forced Fish to withdraw from the 2012 U.S. Open. Now he is open about his mental health and works with the U.S.T.A. to provide more resources for players.
content: The fourth-round singles matches at the U.S. Open were underway on Sunday, and Mardy Fish, the Davis Cup captain and former tennis star, was remembering the moment nine years ago in New York when he sat in the car sobbing with his wife, Stacey, and decided, with her help, that he could not play in the fourth round against Roger Federer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning, Lauren Hirsch and Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Why You Might Not Be Returning to the Office Until Next Year
description: After the Delta variant disrupted plans to reopen after Labor Day, many businesses pushed their targets further out or left them open-ended.
content: Last week, Uber executives huddled on a nighttime video call to make a difficult decision. They considered whether the ride-hailing company should join a growing list of companies once again delaying their return-to-office dates. Soon after, they announced that Uber would fully reopen its offices on Jan. 10, postponed from Oct. 25.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Southern Republicans Cannot Be Trusted With Public Health
description: Some matters are too important to be entrusted to state governments anymore.
content: NASHVILLE — For those of you keeping score at home, here is where things stand in the 2021 National Calamities Sweeps, Southern Division:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ligaya Mishan and Esther Choi
title: The Ethereal Taste of Flowers
description: Attempting to describe the appeal of floral flavors raises a challenging question: What is the relation between taste and smell?
content: IN 1845, NEARLY a year into a punishing 3,000-mile trek through the Australian interior (then still terra incognita to outsiders), the Prussian naturalist Ludwig Leichhardt attempted to eat the fruit of Pandanus spiralis, a tree that huddled at the edges of watering holes. Pandanus is a genus of tropical evergreens that grow in Southeast and South Asia, Oceania and Africa, with leaves that tend to rise and arch in a whorl around the stem and bulbous fruit, whose polyp-like knobs evoke a pineapple’s armor — hence the English name, screw pine. For Leichhardt, initial results were poor: the “rich, mellow pear-like” flesh of the fruit, he wrote, proved to be “hot, and made our lips and tongues very sore.” (Stomach trouble ensued.) Snooping around the remains of campfires abandoned by locals, he deduced that the fruit had to be buried in hot ash, then soaked and roasted before it could be considered edible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: Masks Are Just the Latest School Board Culture War
description: Americans have a long history of taking out their grievances on low-level school officials.
content: America’s school board meetings are out of control.
source.name: The New York Times

title: They Put Everything Into Their Homes. Not One Was Spared in the Flood.
description: The record rainfall from Hurricane Ida appeared to damage every home on one block in Queens, where some families had lived for decades.
content: The sun beat down on homeowners along 153rd Street in Queens as they hauled waterlogged bags of rubbish out to the curb and placed them alongside heaps of splintered tables, stained mattresses and other vestiges of their lives before the flood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Gendler
title: 2021 U.S. Open: What to Watch on Monday
description: Novak Djokovic looks to fend off the surging Jenson Brooksby as a slew of crowd favorites clash in the round of 16.
content: How to watch: From 11 a.m. to 11 p.m. Eastern time on ESPN2; and streaming on the ESPN app. In Canada on TSN from 11 a.m. to 11 p.m.; and streaming on TSN.ca and the TSN app.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: New York and New Jersey Residents to Receive Federal Aid After Storm
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York has estimated the state suffered at least $50 million in damages.
content: The governors of New York and New Jersey announced on Monday that they had been granted federal aid money from the Biden administration, which declared areas in both states major disaster zones following the torrential rains and catastrophic flooding last week from the remnants of Hurricane Ida.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: How Vision Loss Can Affect the Brain
description: A growing body of evidence suggests that when older people’s brains have to work harder to see, declines in language, memory, attention and more could follow.
content: Medical practice tends to divide its clients — you and me — into specialties defined by body parts: ophthalmology, neurology, gastroenterology, psychiatry and the like. But in fact, the human body doesn’t function in silos. Rather, it works as an integrated whole, and what goes awry in one part of the body can affect several others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: California Bill Could Alter Amazon Labor Practices
description: The bill would rein in production quotas at warehouses that critics say are excessive and force workers to forgo bathroom breaks.
content: Among the pandemic’s biggest economic winners is Amazon, which nearly doubled its annual profit last year to $21 billion and is on pace to far exceed that total this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: For a Second Year, Jews Mark the High Holy Days in the Shadow of Covid
description: Many synagogues are holding in-person services, but some are requiring worshipers to show proof of vaccination and to wear masks.
content: The leadership at Central Synagogue in Manhattan had big plans this year for the Jewish High Holy Days: After celebrating via livestream during the pandemic last fall, they rented out Radio City Music Hall for a grand celebration.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Sept. 6, 2021
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Sept. 6, 2021.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Reinhard and Jugal K. Patel
title: Caldor Fire’s March to the Edge of South Lake Tahoe
description: The Caldor fire is now the second-largest fire actively burning in California, a state that sets new records for wildfires each year.
content: The Caldor fire is now the second-largest fire actively burning in California, a state that sets new records for wildfires each year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Steven Pinker Thinks Your Sense of Imminent Doom Is Wrong
description: “It is irrational to interpret a number of crises occurring at the same time as signs that we’re doomed.”
content: “It is irrational to interpret a number of crises occurring at the same time as signs that we’re doomed.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $4.8 Million in California
description: A 1939 Georgian Revival-style estate in Monterey, a beachfront home in San Clemente and a 1928 Mediterranean-style house in San Marino.
content: A 1939 Georgian Revival-style estate in Monterey, a beachfront home in San Clemente and a 1928 Mediterranean-style house in San Marino.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘A Bucket List at the End of Life Is a Lot of Pressure’
description: Readers offer their thoughts about living and dying. Also: Unvaccinated tennis players; abuse of flight attendants; obsessive-compulsive disorder; ex-offenders.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: A Stew for Labor Day
description: Try a luscious recipe for Jamaican oxtail stew, or get to grilling for the holiday.
content: Good morning. Happy Labor Day. Because of the coronavirus there’ll be no West Indian American Day Parade this year along Eastern Parkway in Brooklyn, but if you’d like to get into the spirit of past and future holidays, you might try this luscious Jamaican oxtail stew (above) that I learned to make a decade ago by pestering the team at the Golden Krust Caribbean Bakery and Grill until they gave me the scaffolding of a recipe. That and some coconut rice can make for a beautiful evening, a taste of barefoot late summer, spicy and rich.
source.name: The New York Times
